sen.j: 三門（さんもん）とは寺院の正面に配置される門のこと。
sen.e: The term "Sanmon" refers to a gate located in front of a temple.

sen.j: 三門は空門・無相門・無願門の三境地を経て仏国土に至る門、三解脱門（さんげだつもん）を表すとされる。
sen.e: Sanmon is assumed to represent Sangedatsumon (Three Gates of Liberation), which consists of three gates symbolizing three mental states, that is, kumon (gate symbolizing emptiness), musomon (gate symbolizing formlessness) and muganmon (gate symbolizing desirelessness), to pass through before reaching the Buddhist paradise.

sen.j: 建築史的見解では、初期の寺院の門構えは南面する正門、東西二つの副門から構成されており、これを称して三門と呼んだという。
sen.e: From the viewpoint of architectural history, it is said that a main gate facing the south and two auxiliary gates facing the east and west, respectively, as provided for temples of ancient times, were called Sanmon.

sen.j: 三門の名称の由来は、貪・瞋・痴の三煩を解脱する境界の門、声聞・縁覚・菩薩の三乗が通る門などの説がある。
sen.e: With regard to the derivation of the term "Sanmon", there are several opinions, including the following: Gates to pass through in order to be delivered from the three evil passions, that is, avarice, anger and stupidity; Gates passed through by the Three Vehicles carrying sentient beings to the world of enlightenment (referring actually to the three divisions of the teachings of Buddha), as follows: the teachings of Shomon (hearers) that cause one to understand Buddhism by listening to others' talking; the teachings of Engaku (self-enlightened saints) that cause one to understand Buddhism by oneself in daily life; the teachings of Bosatsu (Buddhist saints) that cause one to seek enlightenment and also try to lead others to attain Buddhahood.
sen.cmt: 「声聞・縁覚・菩薩」：人物そのものに言及しているのではなく、三乗としての教えを意味しているので、そのように訳出しました。また、それぞれの教えの内容にも簡単に触れた方が良いと考え、情報を追加してあります。不要であれば、コロン以下の各項目の"that cause"以下を削除してください。
sen.e: With regards to the derivation of the term "Sanmon", there are several opinions, including the following: Gates passed through by the Three Vehicles carrying sentient beings to the world of enlightenment (referring actually to the three divisions of the teachings of Buddha), as follows: the teachings of Shomon (hearers) that cause one to understand Buddhism by listening to others' talking; the teachings of Engaku (self-enlightened saints) that cause one to understand Buddhism by oneself in daily life; the teachings of Bosatsu (Buddhist saints) that cause one to seek enlightenment and also to try to lead others to attain Buddhahood.

There are several theories as to the derivation of the term Sanmon, including the following: that the term symbolizes the gates one has to pass through in order to be delivered from the three evil passions of avarice, anger and stupidity; or that the term symbolizes the gates to the three paths to Buddhahood of Shomon (learning), Engaku (self-attained enlightenment) and Bosatsu (bodhisattva).
